title: Here Are Five Players Who Are Looking To Break The Federer, Nadal And Djokovic Era Of Dominance
text:
Over the past 15 years, we have become accustomed to the brilliance and badassery of tennis' big three - Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, and Novak Djokovic.

The trio has been calling the shots and imposing their authority for years now, and having been winning for fun. There has be no stopping the three, as they continue to reign supreme on the tennis courts.

The big three of the current era have an astonishing 55 Grand Slam titles between them, and have been simply unstoppable. They are still going strong, but it might not be for long.

With age catching up, and the new breed of stars coming through - the challenge has be thrown to the big three. Roger Federer is 38, Rafael is 33, and Novak Djokovic is 32.

There have been a wave of new tennis players making quite an impression, and even threatening the dominance of big three. Let's look at the five players who are looking to break the Federer, Nadal And Djokovic era of ascendancy:

Daniil Medvedev

AP

Aggressive on the court, humble off it, Daniil Medvedev has all the ingredients of a great player. Not only is he winning on the court, but off it, too. He comes away as shy, but he is nothing of that note on the court.

The 23 year-old Russian has seen a tremendous rise and currently holds the number four spot in the ATP Rankings.

He has won seven ATP singles titles, including two Masters 1000 titles at the 2019 Cincinnati Masters and the 2019 Rolex Shanghai Masters. He has also reached one Grand Slam final at the 2019 US Open, where he was defeated by Rafael Nadal in five sets.

A very tall player with the ability to cover the ground running, he has shown tremendous ability with his racket. He is fast turning into a world beater.

Dominic Thiem

AFP

Another of Tennis' rising stars, Dominic Thiem, has been a consistent performer over the last few seasons. Having reached the finals of French Open in 2018 and 2019, he has shown great character and done the talking on the court.

The 26 year-old Austrian, beat Roger Federer to win his first ATP Masters 1000 title at Indian Wells this year. It is no mean feat to beat arguably the greatest tennis player ever, and Thiem showed why he is one for the future.

He is especially good on clay and is often regarded as the heir to Rafael Nadal. Those are very big boots to fill, but Thiem has to be himself and keep improving. Time is now for him to show he has the mettle to win big tournaments against top opponents.



Alexander Zverev

ATP

If you are good enough, you are old enough - it sets true for the 22 year-old Alexander Zverev. He has been so impressive that Rafael Nadal sees him as the future number one. Praise doesn't come bigger than that.

At such a young age, the German has has won 11 ATP titles in singles and two in doubles. Zverev is also the reigning champion at the ATP Finals, making him the youngest winner at the year-end championship in a decade.

Born in a tennis family, it is hard to see why the world number six is such a good player. On evidence, he is on way to becoming one of the best players.

Stefanos Tsitsipas

ATP

Stefanos Tsitsipas is still only 22, but he is way mature beyond his age. He is the youngest player ranked in the top 10 - currently ranked at number 7.

He earlier reached his career high of number five, thus making him the the highest-ranked Greek player in history. He has won three ATP singles titles and reached seven finals.

Much like Zverev, he comes from a tennis family - his mother was a professional on the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) tour and his father was trained as a tennis coach.

As a junior, he was ranked No. 1 in the world. He also became the third Greek player, and first Greek male in the Open Era, to win a junior Grand Slam title with a victory in the 2016 Wimbledon boys' doubles event.

Still very young, but he has shown promise aplenty and looks to be set for a bright future.

Matteo Berrettini

AFP

Another promising player on the circuit, Matteo Berrettini is another player destined for a bright future. Having already won two ATP tour titles, the 23 year-old has a building reputation of been another talented new kid.

The Italian is starting to find his feet after a difficult start to his career in 2017, when he found it difficult get going. Now after improving, he is beginning to show his true caliber and putting in consistently good performances.

The world number 13 still has long way to go, but he has the right attributes to make it on the big stage.
